title: four devastating ways black brits
story: NewsFour devastating ways black Brits health is suffering because of racismWere looking at some of the biggest issues affecting black lives in Britain todayShareCommentsByAdenike Adenitire:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsEva Simpson is looking at the issues affecting black people in Britain today" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMirror columnist Eva Simpson is looking at the toughest issues facing black people today in Britain as part of the Mirroraposs Black Britain campaign. Here, she explains why itaposs so important. Why in Britain, in , are black people still marching against racism and injustice  In a hard-hitting series, launching today on Windrush Day – the nd anniversary of the Empire Windrush arriving at Tilbury – we’ll look at issues affecting black British lives and why they matter. We start with health. I was honoured to play a role in commissioning a brilliant group of writers who are telling stories long overdue. I hope you read them in the spirit they are written in – a desire to deepen understanding of the issues and create a fairer society, where people are no longer judged by the colour of their skin, but by the content of their character. Mirror writer Adenike Adenitire takes a closer look at four of the most devastating health issues affecting Britainaposs black community. Here is what sheaposs found. Blood cancer  Orin Lewis OBE and we Beverley De-Gale OBE run the charity African Caribbean Leukaemia Trust. For  years it has worked to help patients with blood cancer and other illnesses to find stem cell, blood or organ donors, as there is an extreme shortage in the black community. ACLT was founded in  after the couple’s then six-year-old son Daniel De-Gale became the first black person in the UK to receive a stem cell transplant from an unrelated donor. Daniel unfortunately passed away in  at the age of  as a result of multiple organ failure. Orin says: “There is a pandemic virus called racism that is affecting all sectors of society, including health. The Royal College of Nursing came out last week to admit they’ve got a big problem with how black and other nurses from ethnic minorities are treated. “And we see it because our struggle to fund our work to save lives shouldn’t be this hard after nearly  years.” For details visit aclt.org. Sickle cell Sickle Cell Disease is Britain’s biggest genetic blood disease, affecting , people in the country – mainly those of African and Caribbean heritage. Episodes of excruciating pain may occur, which are treated with strong painkillers such as morphine. Those suffering from the condition are at risk of complications such as a stroke, blindness and bone damage. The disease can also result in deathnot treated properly. Approximately  babies are born with SCD in the UK every year but problems of lack of awareness and funding remain. John James OBE, CEO of Britain’s leading sickle cell charity The Sickle Cell Society, says: “Sickle Cell is something that has been known about for over  years but there has been very limited innovation research and development into modying treatment. Why is that  “Some people would ask: ‘If this was the biggest blood condition in the UK but it was affecting predominantly white people, would it still be the same ’” Dame Elizabeth Anionwu, who won a Letime Achievement Award at the Daily Mirror’s Pride of Britain Awards for transforming care for people with sickle cell disease, agrees that patients can face undue prejudice. She says: “There is still an issue about pain relief. “There are still some iniduals of African or Caribbean heritage, who are patients, but are thought of as drug addicts because they need drugs like morphine.” More information is avilable at sicklecellsociety.org. Mental health As a black person in the UK, you are four times more likely to be detained under the Mental Health Act than a white person, according to data collected from NHS Digital. Figures have shown black men are  times more likely to have serious mental health issues such as bipolar disorder and schizophrenia, yet only % of psychologists are from BAME backgrounds. An independent report conducted by the Centre for Mental Health noted that experiences of racism “appear to be a major influence on the mental health of black boys and young men that wear down their resilience during teenage and young adult years”. The study, which spoke to just under  participants, “found evidence of the incrementally damaging impact of a stream of negative media representations and demonising portrayals of black culture that led men to ‘mask’ their true selves”. Eche Egbuonu’s first experience with mental health issues was during his final year of university. The college lecturer, , from Hackney, East London, said: “There was an identity crisis I went through, where I was surrounded by lots of people but I still felt at my loneliest.” In , he suffered a psychotic episode of mania after having a dispute with his family. The police were called to the home and he was taken to a cell while a bed was prepared for him at a hospital. He says: “Some of the ways they got me into the cell seemed very heavy-handed given the fact that I had not been violent towards the officers or any other inidual. “So I could not understand that level of force or the need to place me in a prison cell.” Child birth  Black women in the UK are five times more likely than white women to die during childbirth according to a  report from Mothers and Babies Reducing Risk Through Audits and Confidential Enquiries. Candice Brathwaite, blogger and author of best-selling book I Am Not Your Baby Mother, understands this only too well after her own experience seven years ago of giving birth to her first child, daughter Esmé-Olivia. The  year-old says: “From beginning to end it was a mess. I was induced and left to wait hours for pain medicine while I was surrounded by labouring white women who seemed to be covered in this maternal care. It really felt like I was an annoyance.” After giving birth, Candice started feeling very unwell and told midwives. She says: “Their attitude was very much ‘you are overthinking it’ and ‘you are just having baby blues’.” But just two days after going home, baby Esmé fell asleep on Candice’s chest and the weight of her tiny body was enough to burst a septic sac growing underneath Candice’s C- section wound.

The haunting images show tables scattered with moulds of human jaws and sets of  teeth implants left strewn across the floor.The building opened as st Dental on Wetherby Road, Harrogate, in , specialising in dental moulds for dental prosthetics but also served as a private general dentist, as reported by Yorkshire Live.Before that, the site was occupied by Aesthetic Dental services. After st Dental was placed into administration in , it was bought out by investment firm Zeus Group, but the branch closed its doors in .Eight years later it remains unused and often attracts youngsters in the town who use it as a place to socialise. Previous attempts to takeover and refurbish the building have failed, with Starbucks submitting three planning applications to open a coffee shop at the address, only to see the plan rejected each time.The site was documented by an urban explorer who posts on Facebook as Lost Places  Forgotten Faces, sharing images and videos from within neglected locations around Yorkshire.  Posting more than  photos, the caption reads: st Dental was a Harrogate based private dental laboratory. Located within the town I live, Iaposve had this old dentist pinned since the beginning, and finally found out it had access. As evident throughout, the youth of Harrogate have used the building as a place to hang out. The building has been badly trashed and vandalised, with graffiti dating back to . Images from the outside show the building to be overgrown and the creepy interior to still have much of the abandoned equipment and documentation left in place. Tables are covered in dental implants to replace missing teeth, medical masks, surgical equipment, documentation, and patient records. Moulds for both inidual teeth and entire jaws have been left to gather dust, along with a cabinet containing drawers full of  teeth.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailJulian Assange managed to fall in love and start a secret family- all while unable to leave the Ecuadorian Embassy in London. Assangeaposs secret fiancée Stella Moris has laid bare her relationship with Mr Assange after the bombshell revelation they had two children during his seven-year stint in the embassy. In an upcoming interview, the South-African born lawyer will reveal she fell in love with the high profile Australian WikiLeaks founder. Mr Assange caught authorities and his followers unawares when it emerged he had fallen in love and managed to start a secret family despite his bunkered le.  The couple conceived two children during embassy visits while she was trying to halt his extraditions to Sweden and the US. Itaposs quite something that one of the most surveyed people on the planet managed to carve out a space for a family and a partner, Mr Assangeaposs fiancée, Ms Moris is set to tell  Minutes reporter Tara Brown in a world exclusive interview. It wasnapost easy, but I thinkyouaposre with someone you love, you can make impossible situations possible. In , a starstruck Ms Moris joined team Assange as a legal researcher. When I first met him, I felt so fortunate that I was able to meet this person who had changed the world really with Wikileaks, Ms Moris says.  It was very romantic and cautious and very sweet. Although the Embassy was an unlikely love nest, by  Mr Assange and Ms Moris were deeply in love.By , the pair were secretly engaged. While she admits that the circumstances were less than ideal to raise a family, she says their love for one another eclipsed their concerns. We loved each other, and we wanted to start a family. All these other circumstances would change but that was a certainty, she says.  I got pregnant and we were over the moon. The couple consider their love affair, along with their children, three-year-old Gabriel and -month-old Max, acts of rebellion. Ms Moris, cautious of prying eyes and ears, even had to write down her big news on a piece of paper in fear of being secretly recorded at the Embassy. When I got pregnant the first time, there were microphones everywhere. I had to write it down on a piece of paper to tell him, she reveals in the interview. Mr Moris never lived in the Embassy and so giving birth and raising the coupleaposs children was very much a solitary affair. But she still pursued a family le with Mr Assange, taking the children to see him whenever possible. In her interview with  Minutes, his partner explains the strict security measures she had to take. You donapost take these steps lightly. You only do thisyou think that thereaposs a very serious security risk. She explained that she hid both her pregnancies from everyone at the Embassy. I thought that our family would be targeted by the same people that were trying to harm Julian in a bid to harm him. Creating an elaborate cover to ensure security and safety, the couple recruited close friend, British actor Stephen Hoo, to pose as their childaposs father in order to sht attention from a compromised Mr Assange. Stephen played the part of doting dad, while Ms Moris would arrive and leave the Embassy separately to hide that she was the babyaposs mother. But security staff at the Embassy were dubious. They collected a dossier on Mr Hoo and also concocted what Ms Morris alleges was a plan to target her eldest child Gabriel and steal his DNA by collecting his nappy and dummy. They had instructions to steal his DNA in order to establish that Julian was the father, and in a bid to hurt Julian, Ms Moris claims in the interview. Itaposs also alleged that recordings of Mr Assangeaposs privileged conversations with his lawyers and doctors were being sent back to America to bolster their pending extradition case against him. Worse, according to the security firm whistle blowers, there was canvassing of plots to forcibly remove Mr Assange from the Embassy and have him killed. I think itaposs hard for people to understand that such lawlessness is possible, Ms Moris says. Thereaposs incredible criminality that has been going on in order to gather information about Julianaposs lawyers, and his family, and journalists who were visiting him. Iaposve been in a permanent state of fear for years and now itaposs slowly playing out. Last April, Julian Assangeaposs political asylum was revoked, and in an unprecedented move, police in London were invited in to arrest him. Few would have known that along with his eviction and arrest, Mr Assange was leaving behind two young children and a long-term partner. Assange took up residence in the Ecuadorian embassy in  to avoid being extradited to Sweden. A rape charge brought by the country’s prosecutors has since been dropped but he is also wanted in America for allegedly leaking classied intelligence documents.

story: NewsMum gives birth to baby weighing the same as a bowling ball during lockdownBrave Emma Fearon, , gave birth to Atticus James Fearon, who weighed lb oz, at her home in Thornton-le-moore, Cheshire, with only gas and air as pain reliefShareCommentsByCharlotte Penketh-KingLorraine King:,  JUN NewsEmma Fearon, , gave birth to Atticus James Fearon " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA mum has given birth during lockdown to one of Britainaposs biggest babies after he came into the world weighing the same as a bowling ball. Emma Fearon welcomed her third child Atticus James Fearon who arrived at a whopping lb oz at her home in Thornton-le-moore, Cheshire. The brave -year-old needed no stitches following the birth and only had gas and air as pain relief during her relatively short labour which lasted under three hours. Emma now has one of the countries biggest families as her firstborn Aria, three, weighed lb oz at birth and her second child Amelia, two, was lb. Emma had Atticus in a birthing pool using hypnobirthing techniques set up at her home. She said: aposaposI birthed him in a pool with the midwe arriving with only half an hour to spare. aposaposI only had a couple of puffs of gas and air and got away with no stitches. aposIt just goes to show what womenaposs bodies are capable of and a nice reassurance for those that are predicted to have big babies. The birth went amazingly - I used hypnobirthing to calm and ground me and the labour was only two and a half hours long start to finish. Iaposm really pleased that I got to give birth at home as I would have had to go alone to the hospitalnot with my husband staying at home with the girls. I had planned to have a home birth from the start and was concerned when NHS trusts started to close down the home birth service as I was so dead set on it. I researched unassisted birthing and then ended up hiring two independent midwives so that I could definitely have the birth that I wanted and felt this was the safest. The midwives were very supportive and werenapost concerned about his size - they both felt that your body would not produce a baby that you canapost give birth to and were very encouraging of my plans, although none of us thought heaposd turn out quite so big.aposapos  Baby Aria was born in hospital after a long delivery that required forcep assistance and resulted in a big tear and an episiotomy. Second baby Amelia was also born in hospital but without any issues, leading Emma to decided to have home birth with a birthing pool for her third baby. But she says, whilst money remains incredibly tight, sheaposs actually managed to find a disciplined way to make her finances work for her small family.Vicky told Birmingham Live she is delighted by the news that she will now receive free school meal vouchers over the summer holidays, thanks to a government u-turn following football star Marcus Rashfordaposs campaign.She is sharing how she will use this money to feed them both over the six week break. I donapost class myself as a poor person even though we live below the poverty line, said Vicky, from Mosely, who is a full-time mum to Daniel, five. Itaposs all to do with budgeting and planning exactly what we need. As soon as we get our universal credit payment, I do a big monthly shop but I only buy the things we need. I never buy three-for-two offers and things like that and I donapost buy packets of fruit. Say we have two bananas at home, Iaposll just buy five loose bananas rather than a bag of seven because we donapost need them. We then do a small top-up weekly shop of fresh fruit and vegetables.  I also portion our meals carefully and I donapost allow my son to snack freely throughout the day. He has one snack in the morning and one in the afternoon, like at school, so we know exactly how much we need when we go shopping. Thataposs the dference, itaposs about not buying things you donapost really need but only buying the things you do need, when you need them. The government made a £ million government u-turn on free school meal vouchers after the Prime Minister bowed to pressure from campaigners include England striker Rashford.Rashford had posted a poignant open letter sharing how his family relied on free school meals, piling on pressure on Prime Minister Boris Johnson to make the free schools meals announcement.It now means that every pupil entitled to free school meals in Birmingham will be given food vouchers for six weeks to cover the summer holidays. For Vicky, this means she will receive £ a month to spend on lunches for her son. But with her clever budgeting skills, she believes she can make this money stretch even further. A total of  people have now been diagnosed at the Two Sisters chicken factory in Llangefni, Anglesey.Public Health Wales said that  more people linked to the meat plant had tested positive as of pm on Sunday - in addition to the  who had tested positive as of pm on Saturday. Dr Christopher Johnson, Consultant in Health Protection at Public Health Wales said: “Since we commenced targeted testing last Thursday, over  members of staff have provided samples so far. Testing of employees continues, and it is likely that some additional cases will be identied in coming days.Follow all coronavirus updates on our live blog here“The increase in cases is as we anticipated when a focused track and trace programme is implemented, and does not mean that the spread of infection is increasing.First Minister Mark Drakeford had initially said that he thought local lockdowns were unlikely to be used in Wales, reports WalesOnline.But in recent weeks both he and Health Minister Vaughan Gething have indicated they are likely to be part of the Welsh Governmentaposs plans. And now it appears that they are being considered in north Wales right now just as the First Minister announced a loosening of restrictions across the nation from Monday with shops reopening.Economy Minister Ken Skates told ITV  that weaposve not ruled that out a local lockdown on Anglesey because it would be more desirable than pushing the entire country back into a full lockdown.He added: In order to deal with these localised spikes itaposs essential that all public bodies and employers work together immediately to test, to track, and to protect people from further fallout from the virus.  We have in Wales a very successful test, track and protect system that has been rolled out at a local authority level. That enabled us to intervene instantly such as that which weaposve seen on Anglesey. There have been coronavirus outbreaks linked to meat plants reported across the UK and Europe. In Germany, , infections have been linked to a slaughterhouse in the north-western region of Bielefeld. In Wales, there have been outbreaks at Rowan Foods in Wrexham and  Sisters in Llangefni. And there has been an outbreak at a Yorkshire plant that supplies bacon to Asda where  staff have been infected. New figures released on Sunday by Public Health Wales show that there have been  new cases of Covid- reported to it in Wales in the last  hours. These will not include most of the new cases related to the Llangefni plant, which are likely to be recorded in Mondayaposs figure.  Sundayaposs rise of  is the largest hike in the daily figures since May th when there were  cases and takes the total number of lab-confirmed infections Wales has seen to ,. In total  of the people newly diagnosed with Covid- live in Anglesey and  in Gwynedd. Eight live in Flintshire, six in Denbighshire and  in Conwy. There were also  people who address is currently unknown. Away from north Wales, there were no cases reported in Swansea, Bridgend, Newport, Caerphilly, Torfaen, the Vale of Glamorgan, Pembrokeshire and Merthyr Tydfil. In its statement on Sunday, Dr Johnson of Public Health Wales said: “I would like to thank the workforce and wider community for their swt co-operation with this test and trace process. This rapid response is providing vital information to help minimise the further spread of COVID- locally. “We must remember that COVID- has not gone away. Incidents like this show the potential for pockets of asymptomatic undiagnosed infection in the community, highlighting the importance of the adherence to social distancing and hygiene measures. “The deployment of rapid test and trace facilities has helped identy this situation and we will continue to keep control measures in place to bring the outbreak to a rapid conclusion. “It therefore remains essential that all members of the public, including employees of  Sisters Food Group and their close contacts, continue to recognise the vital role they have in preventing the spread of Coronavirus, to help keep Wales safe.

title: paramedic dad spends fathers day
story: NewsParamedic dad spends Fathers Day alone to protect we and children from coronavirusAndrew Cox from Thamesmead, London works for the London Ambulance Service and is currently living in a hotel in Greenwich so he doesnt put his family at riskShareCommentsByAmy SharpeLucy Skoulding:,  JUN NewsAndrew urges others to be safe this Fathers Day" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A paramedic dad has decided to spend Father’s Day alone to protect his we and young children from the dangers of coronavirus.Andrew Cox is keeping his distance as his we Shelley, , has Crohn’s disease, which puts her in a high-risk category and makes living as a family too risky at the moment. He is one of  London Ambulance Service staff to have moved into temporary accommodation since the start of lockdown so they could stay on the frontline while protecting loved ones. The couple and their children Phoebe, six, and George, two, are postponing Father’s Day until they can all be together again. Andrew, , said: It has been dficult being away from the kids and I really miss them - but I know it’s a small price to pay to protect them and Shelley. George is too young to understand, but Phoebe is a little bit older and gets why I have to stay away and the important work all parents in the NHS are doing to keep everyone safe. Between shts Andrew - who works on fast-response vehicles treating le-threatening cases - stays at a hotel in Greenwich, south-east London, six miles from his family home in Thamesmead. He is on a five-week rota that allows him to work three weeks and self-isolate in his hotel room on the fourth - so he can be reunited with his young children on the fth. Paramedic of  years Andrew said: The novelty of having peace and quiet after -hour shts quickly wore off! I miss the children pestering me - though Phoebe will FaceTime me three times a day and I’ll go round to wave at the kids from outside the flat twice a week. It has been a worry as Shelley was not well and in hospital before lockdown and she is in the middle of a flare-up at the moment - possibly linked to stress. As she can’t leave the house I sometimes pick up food shopping and help take the bins out. She leaves them outside the main flat entrance so I can pick up and take them down. Having that one week out of five together just makes it bearable, though George has started to realise what it means when I put my green unorm on again and cries when I leave – knowing it will be a month before I see him again. The dad has been busy during lockdown, working overtime to support his family and adapting to safety measures when treating patients.  He said: Every patient is approached as a suspected Covid- case until proven otherwise. The biggest challenge has been getting to grips with working in PPE as it’s a personal job with lots of contact. Being a dad, when I deal with kids I normally have a good rapport with them, but that’s hard to do behind a mask.

title: single dad 35 who adopted
story: NewsSingle dad, , who adopted six kids will have bittersweet Fathers Day after sons deathAmazing dad Ben Carpenter has adopted six children but losing one of his sons has been a hard experience for the -year-oldShareByPoppy Danby:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsDad Ben Carpenter said Noahs death left him numb " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailCuddles won’t be in short supply today for Ben Carpenter – but it’s a bittersweet Father’s Day for this extraordinary dad. For missing from today’s fun is little Noah, who would have turned three this weekend. The adopted toddler died last November after a stomach infection led to complications. Ben was devastated. But with four other adopted children to focus on – each one with their own needs – he was determined to ensure happy memories of the boy they had lost. The children made a memory tree in disabled Noah’s honour – covered in rainbows and crystals. And there are photos of him in every room. Ben says: “The children sang a lullaby to Noah at his funeral. “My eldest always says good morning to him. And my daughter takes his teddy with her wherever she goes.” Ben also bought a card to mark what should have been Noah’s birthday. He adds: “It’s made me realise, you’ve got to make the most of every moment. And that’s what Noah did. “He may have been a little boy in a wheelchair but he had so much le about him. He taught people a lot.”  Single Ben is also dad to Jack, , Ruby, nine, Lilly, seven, and Joseph, four. And a new member of the family has arrived – a -month-old boy. Ben hopes to complete the adoption process soon. He goes on: “At one stage I thought there’s no way I can go through with this and adopt again. And there was an element of ‘am I trying to replace Noah ’ “But then I realised this little boy needs me, just as much as Noah needed me and the other children needed me. And the fact of the matter is, I could never replace him. “We’re hoping to have a picnic for Father’s Day. It’s going to be sad but I’m going to have pictures of Noah in the garden too, so he can be there with us. “I’m still Noah’s father, whether he’s here or not. I’m a father of six, but now I’m only caring for five.” Ben, from West Yorkshire, was  when he first applied to adopt. A couple of years later he welcomed Jack, who has autism and linked obsessive compulsive disorder. But under Ben’s care he has thrived.  Ben then went on to adopt blind Ruby, whose other conditions include spine curvature and limited use of her arms. He is also dad to Ruby’s half-sister Lilly, who is deaf, as well as Joseph, who has Down Syndrome. And the latest member of the family has “quite severe complex needs”, says Ben. Reflecting on Noah, he recalls the awful day the lad slipped away after falling ill. Noah had the rare condition Cornelia de Lange Syndrome. Sufferers have masses of hair. Noah also suffered deformities in his arms and had to be tube fed. Ben says: “I took him to the hospital the day before he died and they sent him home and said he had a viral infection. “The next day we got up, I put him in his chair and went to fetch his medication. When I came back he’d passed away. I tried to resuscitate him but there was nothing I could do.”

title: tragic alexs story saved 12
story: NewsPic of tragic Alex  hours before he died saves  kids from rare Covid- conditionEXCLUSIVE: Baby Alexander Parsons was killed by the rare condition PIMS-TS, but his story has saved other childrens livesShareCommentsByGrace Macaskillkelly jenkins:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsAlexander Parsons from Plymouth who was just eight-months-old when he died " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailTwelve children have been saved after the Sunday Mirror raised awareness of a deadly new disease linked to Covid-. Kerry Postlethwaite was among parents shocked by our story about baby Alexander Parsons, who was killed by the rare condition PIMS-TS. Two days later her own son Joseph, eight, fell ill with matching symptoms . Mum-of-three Kerry, , of Anstey, Leics, said: “Joseph had Covid-like symptoms in March but they disappeared. A couple of days after reading about Alex, he developed the same cough and temperature out of the blue and said he also had a tummy ache. “I called  and they suggested we get him a test for Covid, but I couldn’t get Alex’s story out of my head. “Next day Joseph developed a sun-burn rash. He’d been in the paddling pool but was slathered in sunscreen. “That was the one thing that stood out for me. It was like a clock ticking. “I called  again and luckily they knew about the symptoms.” Joseph was taken to Leicester Infirmary where tests revealed one of his heart arteries was inflamed. Kerry added: “It was awful. Joseph said the pain in his heart made him crazy because it was hurting and asked mehe was going to die.  You are trying to fight back tears but you are mummy and you have to kiss it better evenyou don’t know things are going to be okay.” Joseph was given immunoglobulin – which helps destroy viruses – and released from hospital six days later. Kerry added: “I’ll be forever grateful to the family for finding the courage to share Alex’s story. It saved Joseph.” Alex was just eight months old. His mum Kathryn, , from Plymouth, said: “Losing Alex is awful but the fact our beautul boy could have saved other children’s lives is the one positive that can be taken from his death.  We’re so proud of him. “The fact people looked at Alex’s little face and took in the information that potentially saved their children is the best legacy we could ask for. A dozen or more families have been in touch with us to say they recognised their child had symptoms after reading about Alex. I’m so proud Alex has helped do this. He was amazing and had an impact on every single person he met.”  We can reveal  British children have ended up in intensive care with PIMS-TS since March. Just like Kawasaki disease, it inflames blood vessels as the body’s immune system goes into overdrive to fight Covid- infection.  The president of the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health, Professor Russell Viner, was so concerned by the emergence of the condition that he wrote to NHS England on the day Alex died. That alert helped doctors diagnose Leia Godwin, who spent four weeks in hospital after being hit by the disease.Six-month-old Leia, of Risca, South Wales, had a high temperature and rash while her identical twin Thea had no symptoms at all. Antibody tests showed Leia had coronavirus in the past.The twins could now hold the key to why Covid- affects some people more badly than others. Doctors at the Noah’s Ark Children’s Hospital in Cardf have taken blood samples for genetic testing. Mum Hannah Godwin, , said: “Leia had a rash on her feet and I think the doctors initially thought it was septicaemia or meningitis. But then the alert about Alex was issued.“I believe his doctors were in touch with ours and we know we are lucky to have Leia home. It was such a scary time and she was so poorly. “Doctors don’t yet know why Leia got ill and Thea didn’t. We’ve given them permission to do whatever research they need to help other people.” As many as  British children have developed the condition. London’s Imperial College examined  and found a range of symptoms from a high temperature and abdominal pain to conjunctivitis and coronary inflammation. All the youngsters had a fever. Just over half had a rash.  Elizabeth Whittaker, a consultant in paediatric infectious diseases and immunology at Imperial, said: “We know there have been fewer than  but more than  UK cases. “This isn’t going away. At the beginning there was a huge influx of cases. That settled down, but I think we will see a few new cases every week.” Her colleague Professor Michael Levin said more blood tests must be carried out on children suspected to have the condition. Alex is believed to be the first British child killed by PIMS-TS. His family is campaigning for greater awareness – backed by the parents of a five-year-old who nearly died.

But in his role of chief executive officer at Centrepoint, Seyi Obakin OBE has spent a lot of time with Prince William, teaching him about the homeless charityaposs work and mission. The Duke of Cambridge is so committed to learning about the issue among young people that he spent a night sleeping on the streets with Seyi back in . He first visited one of their centres when he was child as his mum Princess Diana wanted him and Prince Harry to understand the issue, and has been passionate about their work ever since. He became patron in  - his first royal patronage when he was just , the same age many users are when they first receive support from the charity - and has spent the past  years learning, raising awareness and helping their cause in any way he way. Speaking to the Mirror, Seyi said: He was introduced to this problem early in his le. We were over the moon and delighted [when he wanted to be our patron]. The Princess of Wales, Diana, was our patron for many years, and then we had several years after she passed on when we didnapost have a patron at all. It was a great feeling for us that William wanted to carry on. I think it says something about an incredible testament to his motheraposs legacy that he wanted to be patron of Centrepoint and remain involved in finding a way through homelessness. He has a voice that most of us will never have, I think it is to his immense credit that heaposs happy to use that for the benefit of homeless people. I for one am grateful that he doe that. Speaking about the charity in  to mark its th anniversary, William recalled his visit with Diana as a child. He said: That example of selfless service that Centrepoint represents has stayed with me, and that is why it was the first charity that I wanted to be associated with. The extraordinary courage of so many of Centrepoint’s young people in rising to meet such seemingly insurmountable challenges in their lives. In order to do this, William carries out both private and public visits.  Public visits - the ones you read about in newspapers and see photos from on social media - are designed to raise awareness of the cause. However the private visits, which are done behind closed doors, are very dferent. Seyi said: We are working with some of the most vulnerable young people in the country. At public visits there are flashing lights and cameras, itaposs not the best time for young people to open up and thataposs what private visits can do. Those private visits are time when traumatised and vulnerable people are freer in his presence.  There are no cameras there, there are no journalists there. Theyaposre not worrying about whether what theyaposre saying might end up in the newspapers. He comes and he chats with young people, because thataposs when heaposs able to motivate and inspire on a one-to-one basis. He encourages young people to reach out to wherever their talents might take them. Prince William has an incredible gt, a talent, to put people at ease. I have seen young people chatting to him like old friends within minutes, I donapost think many people can do that.  The most powerful thing when he visits is that he can be so informal and easy to get on with. If you are a young person, often what happens is you donapost even know heaposs coming. You hear that Prince William is here. The first thing that happens, is you can get quite nervous - youaposll lost for words. But his own informality helps young people to break that down. He can have great conversations with young people that are really helpful to them. Itaposs an incredible thing, that heaposs able to do that.  Seyi shared one story that sticks in his mind about Williamaposs ability to make people feel at ease. I was at an event with him several years ago and he met this young person. She knew he was coming and she had completely clammed up and couldnapost get her words out. The prince bends down and whispered into the ears of this young person and it was like a flood gate. She started talking and couldnapost stop. Thataposs what itaposs like. In his role, William spends time learning about the issue of homelessness by meeting people who have been affected and those helping them. He is also an advocate for the issue, and Seyi says he also challenges us to do better, helping the charity to grow.  As part of his quest to understand more about homelessness, William spent a night sleeping on the streets with Seyi in . They decided to do it in December, which meant temperatures dropped as low as minus C. Speaking at the time, William said: I was very struck by the people I met and what they were struggling with – sleeping rough, sofa surfing, not having basic comforts a lot of us take for granted. That really struck me at a young age, bearing in mind the gulf for me, growing up in a palace, and seeing the other end of the spectrum where others were faced with huge personal challenges and were overcoming them. That was powerful to see at a young age. Seyi says William is also extremely passionate about their cause and wants to help in any way he can, and that he also remembers people he has spoken to them and checks in on their progress months later.  He said: He must meet thousands of people every year, and yet he has this incredible capacity to remember those heaposs met and ask after them several months later. Imagine youaposre a young person, and you find yourself cooking, eating and chatting with Prince William in private. Imagine what that does to motivate you. Knowing also, that in three months time, he might be asking how youaposre getting on. Itaposs hugely powerful and inspiring. Weaposve lucky to have him in our corner. Seyi says that William is also very approachable and jokes about with the users. He recalls a time when a young person stared at him, trying to work out why he recognised him.  They told him: You look like somebody famous. You look like Prince William, to which the Duke replied: Yeah, yeah, a lot of people have said that before and just carried on with his work. Like all charities, Centerpoint has had to adapt to the coronavirus lockdown, working in extremely dficult circumstances to ensure they can still help people. Theyaposve struggled with both fundraising and the logistics of services, trying to work out how to do what they do with social distancing and PPE.

story: NewsWoman who lost voice for  months finally gets it back - but now speaks  accentsEmily Egan has been diagnosed with foreign accent syndrome - a rare speech disorder caused by brain damage - meaning her voice rapidly changes between Polish, Russian, French and ItalianShareCommentsByCharlotte Penketh-KingSam Truelove:,  JUN NewsEmily Egan lost the ability to speak for two months " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA woman who was unable to speak for two months due to a mystery brain injury has regained her voice - but can now speak four dferent accents. Emily Egan, , went mute in January this year and doctors were left confused after countless tests failed to explain why or flag up a known condition. By the end of March, Emily finally began to speak again, but her voice sounded nothing like the Essex accent she had before. Emily now mostly speaks with a Polish accent - even in aposbroken Englishapos at times - but her voice can suddenly change to sound French and Italian as well. If she experiences a lot of stress, her accent becomes Russian, and when she is exhausted, Emily can lose the ability to speak altogether. This whole experience has been exhausting and totally overwhelming, Emily said. Itaposs not just my accent that has changed - I donapost speak or think in the same way as before this and I canapost construct sentences like I used to. I write dferently now, my whole vocabulary has changed and my English has gotten worse despite living in the UK all of my le. My dad has said that I donapost sound like me any more in that heaposd never imagine me wording things like I do now.Iaposve even experienced abuse from strangers who think I am foreign - I had a man shout at me in the supermarket saying foreigners like me are the reason we have coronavirus.Itaposs changed my le completely. After months of confusion, Emily has finally been diagnosed with foreign accent syndrome - a rare speech disorder caused by brain damage. Medics initially suspected a stroke, but it was ruled out and they believe her speech disorder was caused by brain damage - but donapost yet know what caused itIt all began after Emily began suffering from headaches for two weeks before her voice suddenly deepened while she was working at the childrenaposs home she manages in Bournemouth in January earlier this year. Her speech rapidly became slow and slurred - a key indication of a stroke - so Emily was rushed to hospital where she underwent extensive CT and MRI scans. Doctors ruled out a stroke but were left confused when Emily lost the ability to speak completely during her hospital stay. She was discharged to a neurologist after three weeks in hospital but still without a voice, and communicated solely through an app on her phone. She said: I knew a bit of basic sign language as I needed it for work years ago but I just used my hands to express what I wanted to say. I had to use a apostext to speakapos app on my iPhone which sounded like Stephen Hawkins and it just wasnapost me. Adjusting to communicating like this was so hard, I felt like a completely dferent person.  Emily and her partner Bradleigh, , had booked a holiday to Thailand before she fell ill and her neurologist encouraged her to take the trip and try to relax as much as possible. Five days into her holiday in March, Emily slowly began to speak again but with great dficulty and she said she sounded deaf. Her voice slowly grew stronger as the days passed but Emily was shocked when she realised she had developed an Eastern European accent. She was diagnosed with foreign accent syndrome after ing from Thailand and now her voice rapidly changes between Polish, Russian, French and Italian.  Emily said: Iaposm an Essex girl normally - my accent was really strong and my voice was very high pitched and really recognisable, people always knew it was me calling. On holiday, I started making sounds like a deaf person trying to talk - it is thought that the neuropathways had started to open as my body had completely relaxed. By the time I was home, the words were sounding like a foreign language. I was so thrilled when my voice started coming back but now I donapost even recognise the voice that comes out of my mouth, it doesnapost sound like me. I actually used to be so good at putting on accents for my friends before this and Iaposve even had people askIaposm putting it on - asI could keep it up this long!  Since her diagnosis, Emily has been having private vocal therapy once a week over Zoom but there is no indicationshe will ever regain her normal accent. Her extremely rare condition has sent her body into shut down, leaving her exhausted and she experienced left side weakness two weeks ago. Again a symptom of a stroke, Emily was rushed to hospital and has now been diagnosed with a al neurological disorder as well. Her left arm and hand are now paralysed but doctors hope she will regain feeling and movement with time and physical therapy. Emily said: Iaposm only  years old and I am shocked at how much my le has changed in a matter of months. Iaposve had to stop working because my job is quite stressful and the doctors have said stress will only make my condition worse. The hardest thing for me is learning that this voice is ok. I have to learn to accept that itaposs ok for me to not be able to get the words out straight away, itaposll come eventually.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe best friend of Madeleine McCann suspect Christian Brueckner has dramatically claimed “I know he did it.” Michael Tatschl lived with the German paedophile in Praia da Luz, where Madeleine vanished. He said: “He was a pervert and more than capable of snatching a child for sexual kicks or money.” We can reveal that Austrian drter Mr Tatschl was grilled last year by German and Austrian police investigating Madeleine’s disappearance.He reportedly told them how his pal bragged about burgling rich tourists’ holiday apartments.  Mr Tatschl, , claimed that Brueckner, , also boasted about “selling kids” – although there as been no evidence found of this so far – and he fears Madeleine was sold to a sex ring.  He claimed: “He was always bragging about money and making money. He even talked about selling kids, maybe to Morocco. “I think he probably sold Maddie to someone. Maybe a sex ring. I was living with him at the time. He was my best friend. I know he did it.” Mr Tatschl claimed that Brueckner was obsessed with the dark web and suspects he used it to deal in pornography and drugs.He also claimed Brueckner had a secret spot in his home in Praia da Lux where he kept stolen loot. Mr Tatschl’s name emerged last week after Portuguese authorities granted access to Brueckner’s court records.They showed Brueckner was locked up on remand with Mr Tatschl after they were caught stealing diesel from lorries.Mr Tatschl, a dad of one who is now back in his native Austria, said he expects an arrest is “imminent” in Madeleine’s case.In his first ever media interview, he described Brueckner as a “strange character”. He said: “He was definitely a pervert. All his friends thought that about him. He had some sexual issues.I really hope they can finally close this case for the family and find Christian guilty for what he has done. He needs to admit it to the police.”  rueckner befriended Mr Tatschl in late . Mr Tatschl began living with him in early  at his farmhouse in Praia da Luz, Algarve, which Brueckner shared with his German girlfriend. Mr Tatschl said: “I was staying at his house and camping in a van in the garden. We spent a lot of time together and had good fun. He did not take drugs at the time but liked to have a drink.” Mr Tatschl claimed that Brueckner bragged about regularly robbing holiday flats.He alleged: “He was a very good burglar and would easily climb up to first-floor apartments when tourists were out.He would steal money, valuables and passports. He had a hiding place in his house, in the roof. He had the money and passports hidden up there.He added: “Christian was always on the dark web. I don’t know exactly what he did but I suspect it involved drugs and pornography.”Mr Tatschl said he was “sucked in” to Brueckner’s le of crime. In April , the pair were caught by police stealing diesel from two lorries in Portimao, Algarve. They spent over eight months on remand in jail awaiting trial. Mr Tatschl claimed that while they were in jail, Brueckner got a pal to clear his home of the alleged stolen loot.He claimed: “He ordered a friend to get rid of any evidence of burglaries or robberies. But this guy and another friend ended up robbing the house and took all the valuables and money. “They also got a video camera from the house, which was how I found out he was a sick b*****d.On that camera was a video of him raping an old woman. It was of this elderly lady who was chained to a wooden post and she was being beaten and raped.”It is not believed that the woman in the video was the American pensioner Brueckner was later convicted of raping and is currently serving jail time for in Germany.After Brueckner’s release from prison, he stayed in Praia da Luz, living in the VW Westfalia van that police later seized.Mr Tatschl said: “I think that confused the police as they were not sure where he was living exactly when Maddie vanished. But he had his van and was living free.” Mr Tatschl moved to the hippy enclave of Orgiva in Andalusia, Spain, in April , weeks before Madeleine, three, vanished on May .He said Brueckner turned up in “late May or early June” driving a Tfin Allegro winnebago. It was in this vehicle that police found a stash of girls’ swimming costumes in .Brueckner also allegedly bragged he could hide “drugs and children” inside the ft-long van.Mr Tatschl said: “He parked it up in Orgiva and came looking for me.“We all wondered where he’d got the money from  It was a big expensive thing. We assumed it was from a big drug deal or something like that. Now I suspect it was Maddie. “He was only there for a couple of days and went on back to Germany. Mr Tatschl lost touch with Brueckner and ed to his native Austria several years ago to start a family. It was while watching last year’s Netflix series The Disappearance of Madeleine McCann that he became convinced his friend was responsible. He claimed: “When I saw the documentary I knew immediately that he was guilty.The part where the female tourist talked about the creepy guy with acne and blond hair, I just knew it was Christian for sure.”Within weeks of the series airing, German and Austrian police knocked on Mr Tatschl’s door. He was interviewed by detectives over two days in April .

title: blether elmwood juniors scotland tracksuits craig brewster
story: Lorraine Cormack requested a photo of her late dad in a football team.Lorraine, from Ambleside Avenue in Kirkton, Dundee, asked: “My dad David Lambird played for Lochee Harp JFC and ious other teams.“I’m not sure of the other teams’ names.“He worked with DC Thomson for  years in the pressroom as a gaffer.“Sadly, he died in January .“I would be really gratefulyou could find any photos of him.”I couldn’t find a Lambird playing for Harp, but the surname cropped up in this Elmwood JFC team photo from season -.Back row– Lambird, Gibson, Gilroy, Harrow, Johnstone, Walker. Front row – Fraser, Crighton, Burke, Lorimer, Grant.Jim Aberdein replied to his own contribution, which featured in our April  issue.Jim had told of the time his junior club Elmwood made the ultimate sacrice of folding, to allowThis, of course, also maintained The Shipbuilders’ claim of being the oldest continual junior football club in Scotland.Jim offered further information from that time, and said: “These were marvellous memories.“I also remember Gus Malone’s fatherwas on the committee of Elmwood at the time.“He was very instrumental in trying to re-form Elmwood JFC after we had taken over the East Craigie name.“When he first applied to the juniors for reinstatement, I am sure it was refused – for reasons which I can’t recall.“I remember he put a team of old and new Elmwood players together on the assumption that we would be back in the league.“He managed to procure a new set of stripsand we played a friendly at North End Park, losing -. That same night, the news came through that the reinstatement had been turned down.“I’m very happy to see that East Craigie are still firmly established in the Scottish Junior Football Association.“I am sure you will have some correspondence on the story and it will be interesting to see and read some of the views.“Keep up the good work.”Younger readers of this column may not remember a senior football competition called the Dewar Shield.This competition featured the County cup holders of Stirlingshire, Forfarshire, Aberdeenshire and Perthshire, and was the brainchild of then Lord Provost of Perth, Mr JA Dewar.It was first competed for in  and ran until .A quirky rule, certainly in the early years, was to pool all the drawings of the matches afterIt wasn’t competed for every year and, occasionally, one tournament would run over more than one season.Of the  competitions, Aberdeen won , while St Johnstone triumphed on eight occasions.Indeed, Saints were the last winners of the trophy.Continuing tales regarding football referees, it was reported in  that: “During the Berwick Rangers v Albion Rovers match, referee Bill Mullen sent a photographer packing when he joined in the players’ protests after a Berwick goal was disallowed”. vw, px"  East Fe East Fe players take a break from training during their promotion-winning season in -.Back row – Pat Quinn, Bertie Miller, John Bernard. Middle row – Johnny Love, Alex Jamieson, Colin McDonald, John Brown, Billy McPhee. Front row – Rab Cairns, Dave Gorman, Jim Finlayson, Brian McNicoll.Five Dundee-based players are in the photo – Jamieson, McDonald, Brown, Finlayson, McNicoll.First-team regulars of that stage of the season missing from the photo include Davie Clarke, Peter McQuade, John Martis, Walter Borthwick and Graeme Honeyman.This photo of the Scotland international team sees them, unusually, in green tracksuits.It was taken before the - draw with England at Wembley in .Back row– Unknown, Alex Hamilton, Bill Brown, Pat Crerand, Billy McNeill , John Greig, Eddie McCreadie. Front row – Ian St John, Willie Henderson, Bobby Collins, Billy Bremner, Denis Law, Davie Wilson.Bremner was the only player not to take part in the game.Robert Johnston saw the photo of the Scotland national team from season - in the March  issue of BwB.It was shown solely to highlight Tommy Docherty’s involvement as an international player.“That was a great photo,” said Robert, of Linlathen, Dundee.“With friends, I’ve been having a discussion regarding that team, and trying to get the names.“We are not sure of a few. Can you oblige by printing it again with all the names ”Glad to do so.Back row– Alex Parker, Eric Caldow, Ian McColl, Tommy Younger, Bobby Evans, Samuel Baird, D Walker . Front row – George Herd, Jimmy Murray, Tommy Docherty, John Mudie, Jim Forrest, Tommy Ewing.Well-known former Dundee junior player and official Alex Duncan recently relayed tales from his connections with Elmwood JFC.Alex also played for close rivals Stobswell and, indeed, co-managed them at one stage.He said: “I was co-manager of Stobswell along with Billy McGann, the former East Fe goalkeeper.“We had a pretty decent side and got better when we signed Craig Brewster as a youngster from Dundee United.“Craig did really well with us and it wasn’t long before senior clubs were looking at him again.“Doug Houston was manager of Forfar Athletic and he invited us to bring up the team for a“After the game, he signed Craig for a fee of £.“Instead of making out the cheque to the club, Billy suggested giving half to Craig, as he wasn’t getting a signing-on fee.“This was agreed . . . £ to Craig and £ to Stobbie.“However, when our secretary Angus Adam found out, he was furious.“So much so that he sacked Billy on the spot!“Angus asked me to take over, but I declined.”Football players, managers and staff are always sought for quotes by the media.I’m continuing to share some of them with you, which are associated with the ScotlandScotland midfielder Scott Brown, speaking in , said: “I think the whole country is sick of sitting at home watching everyone  play.“I was only  the last time Scotland made it to the World Cup Finals – France . It’s so long ago I can hardly remember it.”It’s now  years on, and still no sign of our luck changing! title: tim hortons announces plans to bring coffee cafe to dundee
story: Dundee could be set to get Tayside’s first Tim Hortons cafe # and a former Canadian man can#t wait to queue up.The popular Canadian coffee and doughnut chain has lodged an application to set up a new café and drive-thru at the New Craigie Retail Park on the Kingsway East.Should the application be approved by Dundee City Council the cafe would sell coffee, hot drinks, baked goods, sandwiches and wraps.Punters will be able to get their fill either inside the -seater café or in their cars from a drive-thru window.Jordan Fairlie, a Tayside resident who used to live in Whistler, Canada, says he cannot wait for Tim Hortons to open up in Dundee.He said: “I am so excited about a piece of Canada coming to Tayside.“I will probably go the first day it opens.“There is a kind of cult following in Canada for Tim Hortons, I used to go all the time when I lived there.“The doughnuts are amazing, but the Timbits, which are little balls of doughnut, are the best bit.”Tim Hortons first opened up in Ontario back in , and has proved a popular staple with Canadians ever since.There are now over , Tim Hortons cafes, and since  it has been bringing a taste of the Great White North to Brits in the UK.In a planning application submitted to the local authority, Ryden, on behalf of Tim Hortons UK has said it anticipates the café to be open  hours a day, seven days a week.It is also understood the café, which Tim Hortons UK has been in talks with Dundee City Council with for a year, will create between five and  full time jobs.This development is part of the wider New-Craigie Retail Park, which includes a Lidl supermarket and a number of retail units.Tim Hortons would be built on a section of land that has lain derelict for the past  years.The development as a whole will bring in £. million of capital investment to Dundee,  jobs in the short term, and  in the long term.Should planning permission be granted, this will be Tim Hortons’ th Scottish outlet, with other branches including story: A food bank has bought an electric bike to carry out speedy deliveries after receiving a £, funding boost from Aberdeen Harbour Board.Community Food Initiatives North Eastsay the cargo bike will allow volunteers to deliver fresh food and emergency parcels for those who cannot make their way to the premises for health or mobility reasons.It will ensure the social enterprise can reach those in self-isolation in the Torry, Cove and Kincorth areas to hand out vital supplies throughout the pandemic.Among the usual essential food items being dropped off, there will be growing packs so that families can produce their own vegetables.The bike will also help to reduce the charity#s carbon footprint.The chief executive of Aberdeen Harbour Board, Michelle Handforth, praised the group for title: former oil worker to open high end fashion store in aberdeen shopping centre1
story: At the end of last year, Ryan Steehouder decided to take everything – his income, his career, his le – into his own hands.The s had been a rough decade for the Aberdeen native, with a number of highs and lows, and he wanted to begin the twenties afresh, with an idea that had been at the back of his mind through much of his le.After  years in the oil business, he was going to make a sharp turn and start up his own company – in high-end designer fashion.His new store,  Off in the Galleria, is set to open as soon as lockdown restrictions are eased for shops. vw, px"  However, the sht wasn’t an easy decision to make, particularly considering the rough hand he had been dealt in the preceding years.Ryan, , started in the oil industry almost straight after leaving Aberdeen Grammar School, when he joined the Wood Group and started working in John Wood House.From there he moved between a few jobs in the energy sector, until the oil slump struck in .“I was one of the first to get laid off in November,” said Ryan.What followed was a year and a half of “survival” before he found work again, mainly in offices. But he struggled to shake the idea that there was something he would rather be doing.“I wasn’t enjoying being in an office anymore,” said Ryan.“I decided to pull the trigger when I got to the end of  and I just thought that I wanted to do something dferent.” vw, px"  Fashion was something he had grown up around. He had an uncle who would travel from Lossiemouth to London regularly to meet up with friends and shop around the one-off Alexander McQueen jackets on display.Ryan said: “I like the nicer things in le, and I definitely like the quality that comes with it. The pieces that can last.”He began  with the plan and the time, but just as he was preparing to open, his worst nightmare struck.“When the coronavirus hit, I didn’t think the gamble had paid off. I thought I was going to lose everything again. I still had my car payments, my mortgage payments, I put all my money into the business, and I was just ready to open and start making money again, and then it didn’t happen.“I started thinking I was going to end up bankrupt a few weeks into the coronavirus lockdown.”But instead of panicking, he used the extra time to his advantage.“I thought it might be a few weeks until lockdown is over, so I got in touch with quite a few micro-influencers that I know,” he said.The influencers “lit up Instagram” one Thursday with a minimal, mysterious post pointing towards his store to build hype and curiosity.It worked. His page gained , followers in  hours, and it is still growing ahead of the launch of the physical store in the Galleria, on a date that is yet to be determined.“I’ll announce it on Instagram, to let everyone know that it’s open, then obviously we’ll have socially distancing measures in place. Hopefully very soon.”For now, though, he’s happy with his gamble.“Everyone’s in a refreshed mood and wanting something dferent, and they have a bit of money to spend.“It’s kind of worked out better than it would have been before.”For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.

story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,A big thank you to whoever has tidied up Ardrishaig Community Garden, mown the grass and repaired and painted the fences.Such a peaceful place to call into while out exercising. I can#t wait for the day I can go back there to sit and contemplate, enjoy the views and read or paint.Cheryl Ratclfe-Nye, Ardrishaig.Sir,I would like to thank all the telecommunications workers in Scotland, many of whom have been designated key workers, for how they’ve responded to the coronavirus outbreak.They are providing essential support to the NHS and keeping all of us connected during this dficult time.From the engineers going out to keep our broadband and mobile networks connected, to the vital contact centre staff helping customers when they need it most, they deserve recognition.My colleagues, working with the Scottish Government and NHS, worked quickly to provide the temporary NHS Louisa Jordan hospital in Glasgow with communications. They are doing the same to support other temporary NHS services across Scotland.Our people have worked around the clock with health boards across the country to offer new, technical solutions to help frontline health workers get on with their jobs during this crisis.Our frontline staff in contact centres across Scotland – including Aberdeen, Dundee, Glasgow and Greenock – have risen to this unprecedented challenge. We’ve received a huge surge of customers asking for faster connections to help with home working, home schooling and running their businesses remotely.These colleagues – most of whom can now work from home when they want to – have performed a critical role keeping our customers, including frontline health workers and vulnerable people, connected.The people in our two  contact centres in Scotland are also playing a critical role, answering lesaving emergency calls.I couldn’t be more proud of how my colleagues have responded to these challenges and their desire to help us all through this crisis.Jane Wood, BT Group director in Scotland, Edinburgh.COVID- is seriously not a jokeGlobally kills thousands of folkYou start coughing, you can#t breatheWithout a respirator, this earth you#ll leaveSocial distancing is now in placeKeep two metres apart, not face to faceWash your hands frequently and well hours on surfaces it can dwellShop infrequently, for essentials onlyDon#t mix with othersyou#re lonelyKeep in touch by text and phoneDon#t put yourself at risk, stay aloneIt#s hoped soon this contagion will peakThen we canto normal, so to speakDon#t travel to other towns by carIt can spread the virus near and farSports, socialising and most work on holdThe alternative could cause damage untoldSupport the NHS, essential workers and neighboursThen we#ll defeat this virus by all our laboursDugald MacGilp, Lochgilphead.Sir,We are looking for people who have the passion to bring communities together, believe in the power of co-operation and who hold the well-being of their community at the forefront of their mind.The successful #Member Pioneers# will receive full training and business support as they help groups and iniduals during the coronavirus pandemic and beyond. The pioneers will cover three wide areas: one based around Longrow in Campbeltown, another around The Avenue in Inveraray and a third around Bishopton Road, Lochgilphead.The new positions form part of a drive to recruit , pioneers across the country. Existing pioneers are currently involved in a wide range of activities including co-ordinating food drives and offering personal support to those unable to leave their homes.This has never been more important than now.The local area has so many strengths and we want to help communities be as resilient as possible against the new challenges posed by COVID-. The new pioneers will spearhead our efforts, support great causes and think up new ideas.To apply to be a Member Pioneer, visit jobs.coop member-pioneers. Roles are  hours a month. title: letters to the editor may 22 2020
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,Mental Health Awareness Week, now in its th year, runs from May  to May .This year, the theme for the week is kindness and across the country, people will be celebrating kindness in digital and creative ways within social distancing restrictions.The last couple of months, with all the uncertainty of the virus and the impact of lockdown, have been an extremely stressful and worrying time for many people across the Highlands and Islands. People who may have previously felt isolated in remote and rural communities may be feeling this even more acutely at this time, so it’s important they know support is available.Across the region, many people have also sadly faced the pain of losing loved ones to the virus or have fallen ill themselves, while others have seen their livelihoods put at risk or incomes reduced. All of this has put additional strain on people’s mental well-being.This year’s Mental Health Awareness Week is putting the focus on kindness as a means of helping people through the pandemic and building a better society as we emerge from it. We see many acts of kindness in the Highlands and Islands all the time, but this week is an opportunity for people to reflect on their interactions with others and how they can try and be a little kinder during this unprecedented time.David Stewart, MSP for Highlands and Islands region.Sir,During Mental Health Awareness Week, sight loss charity RNIB Scotland is highlighting the emotional reassurance and practical help it is offering during the coronavirus lockdown.Our Need to Talk telephone counselling service remains available in Argyll and Bute for anyone diagnosed with sight loss, as well as their families, friends and carers.Losing some or even all your sight can be devastating news to take in, but our trained helpers can support you in coming to terms with your condition and finding the way forward.RNIB is concerned the lockdown might be affecting people who are blind and partially sighted, many of whom are older, particularly hard. The uncertainty over access to basic shopping and medication, to information in accessible formats, the social isolation and barriers to being guided because of social distancing can all add and compound to the mental and emotional stress people are experiencing.As well as our Need to Talk service, the RNIB helpline on    is available for anyone with sight loss and we continue to organise social activities over the phone and social media.We want people with sight loss to know they are not alone and that help is available.James Adams, RNIB Scotland director, Edinburgh.The Scottish Invasive Species Initiativehas launched Alien Detectives – a fun and educational online resource to help the young and not so young  learn more about alien # or non-native – invasive species.Originally designed as a school education pack, the huge array of activities now includes a wide range of fun games and activities that anyone can enjoy at home, in the garden or on local walks during lockdown.Alien Detectives includes crafts, quizzes, worksheets, presentations and puzzles all themed around invasive species and the river environment. Although primarily aimed at young people, anyone with an interest in the environment or invasive species can enjoy them too.Our project team has been busy while homeworking during lockdown to produce these fantastic resources. We hope becoming Alien Detectives will bring many hours of enjoyment to iniduals and families during lockdown, especially at a time when most young people are not in a regular school environment and might be looking for a new challenge or activities to continue their learning.Invasive non-native species might be a new topic to many but it is a really important one. Invasive species can have a major impact on our environment and native wildle and are responsible for signicant bioersity loss in Scotland and across the world. We hope these resources will help raise awareness of the impacts of invasive species and inspire more young people to learn something about them.No prior knowledge is needed and there’s lots to learn and have fun with so become an Alien Detective and help us tackle invasive species today.All of the ‘Alien Detectives’ resources can be found at www.invasivespecies.scot alien-detectives.Callum Sinclair, SISI Project Manager, Newton Stewart.Sir,We may not be able to hold picnics in the usual way just yet, but why not hold the next best thing – a virtual picnic  That way you can invite as many people as you want.National charity Family Action is running its Virtual Family Picnic from May  to May  and everyone is invited. The charity has created a free pack full of tips, ideas and videos to help people host their own virtual picnic.You can hold your picnic in your garden, on your balcony or on the living room floor. Just find some space, make some tasty treats and connect with friends and family online.Although we are all still respecting social distancing and cannot meet in groups, we can still share experiences together and create happy memories.  And when lockdown finally ends we can do it all again, but this time in person.To find out more and to get your free pack, visit the Family Action website.David Holmes CBE, Family Action Chief Executive Officer, London

title: memories of tarbert herring and almost moving to loch fyne side
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsIn this time of lockdown, I am reminiscing on great times had in Argyll.I first visited Kintyre with my parents as a -year-old, my family having bought a mini car in . We stayed with Margaret and Iain McDonald at their home named Meadowview in Tarbert which was located near the school.We all enjoyed the area so much that we continued to visit every year for the next consecutive eight years.Margaret invited me to go out on the herring boats once or twice. One was named Village Maid and the other Village Belle and, needless to say, we often had kippers for breakfast, which were very nice. I remember there was a boat called the Southern Cross tied up to Cock Island # can anyone tell me any history of it and when it disappeared There also used to be a smokehouse for kippers along from Tarbert to Ardrishaig.Another fond memory I have is watching the logging trucks unloading on the quay and watching them get loaded on to large boats and I think then being shipped round to Sweden or Finland. Is that correct or not as I thought there was a paper mill at Fort William As mentioned earlier, I joined North West Ambulance Service in the s and Margaret used to send me the Argyllshire Advertiser and in one of them was an advert for recruitment to the Scottish Ambulance Service.I duly got an application form from Paisley and was all but sending the form in when I realised it would be very unfair to move so far away from our young children#s grandparents and for them to be unable to see them growing up. At the time your local pharmacist was retiring and my we Sue was a qualied pharmacist, but our children were both under school age so relied on her parents for child care. Ironically, I believe the job was filled with a Blackpool pharmacist whom I had met ocassionally.My love for Scotland continued, and we had our honeymoon travelling around Scotland and calling in at Tarbert for several days on the trip round.Our last trip up there was  in June as a treat from our daughter who accompanied us on this trip. The weather was glorious, and one day we caught the bus to Skipness and walked part of the Kintyre Way back.Another day we took the MacBrayne Ferry to Islay, which was again a glorious day out, also visited Crinan, Lochgilphead and Inveraray, followed by a couple of days fishing off the pier in Tarbert. We travelled back via Portavadie and Dunoon, and have in the past used the ferry to Arran, then Brodick, Ardrossan and home.Thank you for taking the time to read this. It has been good to share some of the memories of Argyll with you.#

The day was practically observed as a holiday in Kingussie and the special train which conveyed the team to Inverness brought more than  people to see the contest.
