s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentA FAIRTRADE coffee farmer who visited Penarth during Fairtrade Fortnight, has spoken of the plight of rural communities during lockdown in Uganda.Three months ago, Jenipher Wetaka Sambazi, a Fairtrade coffee farmer from the Mt Elgon region in Uganda, was sharing her experiences of the benefit of Fairtrade in Penarthrsquos Tabernacle Baptist Church.More NewsVictory in campaign to save Dinas Powys ancient woodland as dam plan is abandonedVale nurse developed coronavirus symptoms after sitting with patient, inquest toldPenarth RNLI station marks  years despite current coronavirus lockdownNow she and her family, like communities around the world, are under lockdown.In March, campaigners, businesses, supporters, and students from around Wales heard Jenipherrsquos story, face to face.Now she is unable to travel or even meet with her neighbours.This means the coffee picked at the end of the last harvest remains on the mountain and Jenipher and her fellow farmers are prohibited from travelling to gather it for processing under the current lockdown rules.There are currently several hundred known cases of covid- in Uganda, but none in the Mount Elgon region and no fatalities in Uganda as yet.Farmers want to keep it this way, but lockdown is causing other concerns such as limiting access to food and healthcare.This is the time of year when there is the least amount of food available, and the closing of markets and freedom to travel for farmers to source food and water means that times are exceptionally hard.Jenipher as vice-chairwoman of a Fairtrade coffee cooperative, is responsible for many who rely on the cooperative for work.The expert hand-sorters who are seasonal workers and rely on this part of the coffee chain to feed their family at this time, have no coffee to sort.While they may have some spare eggs, vegetables or matoke to trade, the threat of soldiers prohibiting them from doing so is too much for them.Farmer co-operatives, an essential element of Fairtrade, enable and encourage communities to work together.Fairtrade also requires an extra amount of money, the Fairtrade premium, to be paid to producers.Fairtrade farmers like Jenipher are struggling, but they have the benefits of a strong local community as well as the backup of the Fairtrade premium.Fairtrade International have announced a .m euro Fairtrade Producer Relief fund targeting the immediate needs and Resilience Fund to help producers rebuild their businesses after Covid-.Jenipher Wettaka Sambazi said: ldquoLe is hard.ldquoThe markets are shut so there is nowhere to sell or earn money, or to buy food and basic essentials.ldquoLocal health centres have been shut to reduce the chance of spreading the virus, but since all transport is banned, those who need operations, treatment or antenatal care need to walk  km to the nearest hospital.ldquoTwo women and their unborn babies have died on the way."Roger Casey, who attends Tabernacle Baptist Church said: ldquoIt was wonderful to meet Jenipher and hear her story.ldquoWe get through a lot of coffee in our office and meeting a real coffee farmer from Uganda makes you think about the real people and real lives behind that Fairtrade logo.Vale MS Jane Hutt said: ldquoMeeting Jenipher during her visit to Wales earlier this year was inspiring.ldquoThe increasing dficulties facing rural farming communities because of the pandemic has shown how important Fairtrade cooperatives continue to be and I am glad that leaders like Jenipher continue to promote the benefits of Fairtrade and to support communities.National co-ordinator of Fair Trade Wales, Aileen Burmeister added: ldquoFair Trade producers are being impacted by covid- restrictions.ldquoGlobal stock markets are falling, meaning that farmers and workers are receiving far less for their produce."It is in these times that we can really see how important the Fairtrade minimum price is. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey story: Penarth RNLI  - before lockdown " Penarth RNLI celebrates th anniversary - virtuallyPenarth RNLI station. Pic: Penarth RNLI leboat helm, Ben Evans" Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentCREW and supporters of Penarth RNLI are set to celebrate the leboat stationrsquos milestone anniversary.Current covid- lockdown restrictions mean the station is closed, but to mark the official day of reopening, at am on the Wednesday, June  the stationrsquos Facebook followers are invited to a live online QA session.It is hoped that people will be able to share their memories of the leboat and the contribution that the station has made to the local community.Additional events to mark the history of the leboat in Penarth will be promoted throughout the year once lockdown eases.MORE STORIESPenarth RNLI leboat crew rescues people caught out by Bristol Channel tideBarry Dock and Penarth leboats seventh launch to tide stranded people on Sully IslandPenarths RNLI crew on the hunt for new membersPenarthrsquos affiliation with the RNLI first started in , in  the station was closed.However, following a highly successful public campaign an RNLI station was re-established in .The new leboat was housed in a local private garages, but soon a better lsquostationrsquo was developed in the deckchair storebefore moving to its current home, a purpose built station opened in .Gareth Wigmore, one of the first crew members in  and now station president said the leboat was pushed by the crew along the seafront, which at the time wasnrsquot even one way.ldquoWe were as keen as mustard, pleased to be doing our bit for the community, but we had rudimentary equipment back then, he said.ldquoSome of our protective equipment was made by the local community.Crew member Karl Lawrence, with  yearsrsquo experience with the RNLI, said: ldquoThe best part of le-boating is working well as a team.ldquoWe maintain this team spirit by regularly exercising and training both ashore and afloat.ldquoSince opening our new station at the south end of the Esplanade we have installed a training room which is ideal for providing training in a warm, well-lit and stable room, prior to practicing on often rough seas in the leboats.ldquoMy favourite rsquoshoutsrsquo are oddly those which occur in the early hours of the morning on a spring day.ldquoBy the time the job has been completed and the boats are washed down and prepared again for service, we gather on our balcony drinking tea or coffee, watching the sun rise and exchanging with each other our plans for the day ahead, before most other people have woken up.Celebrating the success of the station, current leboat operations manager, Jason Dunlop said ldquoI am incredibly proud to celebrate the stationrsquos -year anniversary.ldquoIt is testament to the community of Penarth who have supported the leboats by providing volunteers, funds, and ongoing support.ldquoThis community effort over the past  years has saved  lives, we have rescued or aided  people and our leboats have launched on service  times.ldquoHundreds of volunteers have supported the RNLI and the station in this time.ldquoI would like to express my thanks to them all and their families.He added: ldquoIt makes no dferencethe role people have played is to crew the boats, to assist launch on shore, provide community safety advice, run our shops or fundraise, everyone plays a vital role in saving lives.ldquoThe RNLI is funded by donations and receives no government funding, soyou are a fundraiser, a member of our shop team, a local business who supports us or a member of the community who has donated or raised funds you have help us to save lives.ldquoWe are all one leboat crew and we are part of the community of Penarth.ldquoThe RNLI is built of the vision that ldquowith courage, nothing is impossible.ldquoI believe that the community of Penarth is a living example of this vision.ldquoAs we say in the RNLI, ldquofair winds and following seas.Leboat spokesman, Andy Berry has asked members the community to send stories and short video messages to awb.safety@gmail where they can be shared online.He said: ldquoMaybe yoursquove been directly involved in a rescue, or perhaps wersquove helped your friends and family  Or maybe you just have a nice story too share about our work or want to wish us well.ldquoWe would love to hear from you.The RNLI, like many charities is facing a funding crisis through the covid- crisis.Penarth RNLI has set up a JustGiving page to help raise monies to mark the th anniversary, with a target of pound.The Penarth Nationwide branch has offered to nominate the Penarth RNLI as their charity of the year.The branch accepts donations and any foreign currency supporters may like to donate. article_url   content_id   site_id title: welsh government first minister announces steps unlock wales
story: Tourism businesses have been put on alert for further changes" Welsh Government first minister announces further steps to unlock WalesRespect the distance at Barry Island" Welsh Government first minister announces further steps to unlock WalesHolton Road could see more busineses re-opening" Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentAll non-essential shops in Wales will be able to re-open from Monday, June  as part the biggest unlocking of the coronavirus regulations to date.Welsh Government first minister, Mark Drakeford announced the change today, Friday, June .Retailers will be able to resume tradingthey can take all reasonable measures to comply with the physical distancing duty in Welsh law to reduce the spread of coronavirus and protect shop workers and shoppers.The changes are part of a comprehensive package of measures being introduced step by step every Monday over the next three weeks.MORE STORIES"Check in, Catch Up. Prepare for summer and September" - Wales schools to enter next phaseWelsh Government lockdown message changed to Stay Local to Keep Wales SafeWelsh Government publishes Unlocking Our Society and Economy: Wales coronavirus roadmapPupils willto schools on Monday, June  and the requirement to stay local will be lted,conditions allow on Monday, July .Mr Drakeford is also alerting the visitor and tourism industry to start preparations to reopenthe spread of the virus continues to decline.He said: ldquoThe threat of coronavirus hasnrsquot gone away but thanks to the efforts we have all made over the last few months, the number of people contracting coronavirus each day in Wales is falling, so too is the risk of meeting somebody with virus.ldquoGiven the progress we have made, we are able to take some additional cautious steps to further unlock our society and economy.ldquoThis includes more retailers being able re-open their businesses, as long as they take measures to minimise the risk to their staff and to the customers who visit their stores.ldquoOur focus continues to be on the health risks of the outbreak, but we can now begin to cautiously focus much more squarely on the wider economic and societal impact the virus is having.ldquoWe have provided a huge amount of support to businesses and jobs as they hibernated during the pandemic ndash now we start to take these careful steps to restart our economy.On Monday, a series of changes will be made to the coronavirus regulations ndash the main change will be to enable non-essential retail businesses to open.They follow the fourth statutory review of the coronavirus regulations by Welsh ministers, using the latest scientic and medical evidence from the UK Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencies , the Welsh Governmentrsquos Technical Advisory Celland the advice from the Chief Medical Officer for Wales.Mondayrsquos changes include enabling private prayer in places of worship where social distancing is maintained and gatherings do not take place restarting the housing market by enabling house viewings to take place in vacant properties and house moves where a sale has been agreed but not yet completed and lting the restrictions on outdoor sports courts, but social distancing must be maintained.No contact or team sports will be allowed.The changes enabling non-professional elite athletes, including Olympic and Paralympic hopefuls, to resume training.On June , pupils willto schools to check in, catch up, and prepare for summer and September under plans announced by education minister, Kirsty Williams.The requirement to stay local and not generally travelling more than five miles from home remains in place.However, new guidance will make it clear people are able to travel outside their local area on compassionate grounds.This includes seeing people at a care home or a youth offender institution ndash when these visits are allowed.People who are eligible to vote in overseas elections, where voting must be done in person, will also be able to travel.Ministers have decided to lt the requirement to stay local on Monday, July  provided the conditions allow.With the requirement lted, people will be able to travel to tourist attractions across Wales.The first minister is also sending a signal to some businesses and the visitor and tourism industry to use this period to begin to make preparations for reopening.At the next review on Thursday, July , the Welsh Government will consider a range of specic options for opening.These include self-contained holiday accommodation and personal care services, such as hairdressing and beauty, by appointment.Discussions will also be held with the hospitality sector about the potential phased reopening of pubs, cafes, and restaurants while maintaining strict social distancing.Mr Drakeford added: ldquoI know the wider tourism industry is keen to reopen and to salvage some of this summerrsquos season.ldquoI am therefore signalling owners of self-contained accommodation should use the next three weeks to prepare to re-open, working with their local communities.ldquoBut I want people to know coronavirus has not gone away.ldquoWe have some headroom to make this package of changes to the regulations, which will be introduced in a phased and cautious way in Wales.ldquoMany aspects of daily le in Wales will be moving into the amber zone in our traffic light system.ldquo But we all need to continue to take steps to protect ourselves from the virus ndash that means working from home wherever possible avoiding unnecessary travel only meeting with one other household outdoors maintaining social distancing and washing your hands often.ldquoIt may also mean wearing a face covering in some situations.ldquoIt is thanks to the efforts of everyone in Wales that we have slowed the spread of coronavirus, but we canrsquot stop now.ldquoWe need to do all we can to protect ourselves and our loved ones from the virus and to keep Wales safe. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey title: vast memorabilia collection david gest sold auction
story: The music supremo was prompted to begin the vast collection thanks to his close friend Michael Jackson ndash an avid collector himself ndash who convinced him he was not buying ldquojunk.Such was its size that following his death in  it filled three lock-up storage units in Liverpool, where he also had an apartment overlooking Sefton Park. vw, px"A signed photograph and dedication to David Gest from Michael Jackson Among the items being sold on behalf of his estate are signed items from his many showbiz friends including Jackson, Whitney Houston, Dionne Warwick, Al Green, Bette Davis, Jane Russell and John Mills.Gest, , found fame in the UK when he appeared in the  edition of the ITV show Irsquom a Celebrity hellip Get Me Out of Here and a decade later he featured in Celebrity Big Brother.In his native US he entered the music industry by starting his own PR business, where his first client was soul singer Green, and he later became a renowned music and concert producer. vw, px"David Gestand soul singer Al Green Gest met Jackson when he was a teenager and his neighbour in Los Angelesrsquos San Fernando Valley.One of the auction lots is  pages of an unpublished book by Gest on Jackson typed on A paper, thought to be dated to , with the opening lines: ldquoThe thought of writing a book about Michael Jackson never really crossed my mind until recently. For one, I hate to write, and secondly, so much has been written about Michael Jackson.ldquoMost of what has been written is untruths and lies, and it was a number of our mutual friends who suggested I write a book to help set the record straight. vw, px"Signed photograph by Whitney Houston with husband Bobby Brown and daughter Bobbi Kristina Brown Jackson was later accused of sexually abusing a -year-old boy ndash with similar allegations to follow ndash but Gest wrote in his  autobiography Simply the Gest that he knew the singer ldquoinside out and was adamant he was innocent.Other items on sale include his birth certicate, his high school graduation yearbook and an engraved Waterford Crystal display piece invitation to his wedding with singer Liza Minnelli in March , who separated just  months later. vw,vw,px, px"High school yearbook of David Gest with his face scribbled out The ultimate David Gest personal collection will go on sale on July  and .For more details of the online auction at Liverpool Auction Rooms visit catocrane or easyliveauction.push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Vast memorabilia collection of David Gest to be sold at auction article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: health minister issues shielding advice
story: Health Minister Robin Swann has announced plans to pause the shielding advice that was issued to people ahead of the Covid- peak in Northern Ireland. From  July, subject to the rate of community transmission continuing to be low, people will no longer need to shield and should instead follow the same guidance and precautions as those considered to be generally vulnerable. That involves taking particular care when out and about - and strictly maintaining social distancing.Letters will be issued in the coming days to all those covered by shielding informing them of the planned change.Mr Swann stated: “I have been clear that shielding would not last one minute longer than it needed to. We have now reached the point where,the current trends continue, there will be no need for anyone to shield after  July. “I have listened to many of you and to the challenges you have faced during this period. I am in no doubt as to the dficulties shielding has presented for a great many people.“It is unrealistic to think these dficulties will just vanish because the need to shield has ended. That is why the letters we issue will provide details of the support which will continue to be available up to and after  July.“While my announcement today will be welcome news for many who are shielding, some will view the prospect of an end to shielding with great anxiety. I want to assure them that they should decide what to do at their own pace. Everyone will approach this situation dferently.“As is so often the case at present, this will be about weighing up the options and making informed choices. Going outside can bring some degree of potential risk but this can be mitigated and minimised by strict social distancing.
